name: Texas Muslim Womens Foundation Inc
mission: Foundation provides education programs to improve well-being in and beyond the Muslim community.
theoryOfChange: A strategic and holistic approach combining immediate crisis intervention (shelters) with long-term stability (transitional housing, senior home) and economic empowerment (Food 4 Good) to break the cycle of violence.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 41/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, humanitarian cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Track and report beneficiary counts to enable cost analysis
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes for 3+ years
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Texas Muslim Womens Foundation Inc earns 64/100 due to strong alignment and good impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.tmwf.org/ways-to-give (Source: https://www.tmwf.org/ways-to-give)

all_citations.claim: The charity has a score of 98.66666666666667/100 and maintains high financial accountability.
The foundation is zakat-eligible and provides information on zakat policy and asnaf categories.
Total revenue was $4,665,216 with a program expense ratio of 86.0%.
The organization provides emergency shelter and support for non-residential domestic violence clients.
The foundation houses survivors in shelters and provides transitional or rapid re-housing.
The charity offers various donation options and giving methods for supporters.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a solid overall rating due to its high financial efficiency and direct provision of critical domestic violence services, though its impact score is moderated by a lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary data.
areas_for_improvement: Increase working capital reserves, which currently sit at 3.7 months, to enhance long-term financial sustainability.
Improve data transparency to raise the current medium data confidence level.

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 41/50, the charity shows a high donor fit for those seeking to support humanitarian causes within a Muslim context [1]. Its zakat-eligible status and focus on urgent humanitarian needs like domestic violence advocacy align closely with the values of many donors [2][8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The foundation demonstrates high financial accountability with a total revenue of $4,665,216 and a program expense ratio of 86.0% [1][3]. While it provides direct services such as emergency shelter and transitional housing for domestic violence survivors, the impact score of 29/50 reflects a medium level of data confidence regarding specific cost-per-beneficiary metrics [4][6].

baseline_narrative.headline: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation provides comprehensive social services and domestic violence support to empower women and families across all communities.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 86.0%, ensuring the vast majority of funds directly support community services.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.03 per $1 raised.
Strong financial health and accountability as evidenced by a Charity Navigator score of 98.66666666666667/100.
baseline_narrative.summary: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation Inc is a non-profit organization dedicated to improving well-being through social services, youth development, and educational programs [1][3]. The foundation is recognized as zakat-eligible, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations through contributions to its various humanitarian initiatives [2][8].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a solid overall rating due to its high financial efficiency and direct provision of critical domestic violence services, though its impact score is moderated by a lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary data.

areas_for_improvement.detail: Current assessments indicate a <cite id="16">small board of only 2 members</cite>, which may present risks to long-term oversight and organizational resilience.

areas_for_improvement.context: While TMWF tracks beneficiary counts, it currently lacks <cite id="17">external evaluations or long-term outcome tracking</cite> to verify the sustained efficacy of its interventions.

bbb_assessment.summary: BBB assessment data is not currently available for this organization.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization is established (founded 2005) and maintains high transparency with its 990 filings.
risk_factors: <cite id="16">Board size of 2 members</cite> is below best-practice standards
<cite id="17">No RCT-level evidence</cite> for long-term outcomes
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="16">governance risks due to a small board</cite> and a lack of <cite id="17">third-party impact evaluations</cite>.

confidence.notes: Strong financial data, but governance and outcome measurement are areas for growth.

alignment.explanation: Alignment is high as the charity is <cite id="8">zakat-eligible</cite> and serves <cite id="9">vulnerable Muslim populations</cite> in a high-urgency humanitarian cause area.

credibility.explanation: TMWF is highly credible due to its <cite id="1">98.98.66666666666667/100 from Charity Navigator score</cite> and <cite id="10">100% independent board</cite>. It has operated for <cite id="18">21 years</cite> with consistent financial reporting.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="16">expand its board of directors</cite> beyond the current two members to ensure more robust governance.

impact.explanation: The foundation provides <cite id="2">direct provision of services</cite> including crisis shelters and food programs. It maintains a <cite id="13">86.0% program expense ratio</cite> and a <cite id="14">healthy working capital of 3.7 months</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="17">tracking and reporting specific cost-per-beneficiary metrics</cite> to demonstrate delivery efficiency.

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service provider; not a primary grantmaker

rich_narrative.headline: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation provides comprehensive social services and domestic violence support to empower women and families across all communities.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support domestic violence survivors and vulnerable families within the American Muslim community through a highly efficient, zakat-eligible local organization.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat obligations with a focus on North Texas
Care about providing immediate safety and housing for domestic violence survivors
Value low overhead and high fundraising efficiency
giving_considerations: Gifts support direct local services rather than international relief
The organization is in a growth phase with a 17.3% revenue CAGR
Governance is currently centralized with a very small board
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking international humanitarian impact or those who require large-scale, third-party academic impact studies.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects consistent internal tracking of beneficiary counts (e.g., shelter residents) without external validation.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: TMWF utilizes a holistic model of 'Peace in the Home' to provide safety, stability, and education to survivors of domestic violence.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Tracking outcomes ensures that shelter and housing programs successfully lead to long-term survivor independence.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a 17.3% growth rate and expanding programs in transitional housing, TMWF can effectively absorb additional capital.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: North Texas (Dallas, Collin, Tarrant, Denton, Rockwall)

peer_comparison.differentiator: TMWF is distinguished by its <cite id="5">exceptionally low fundraising cost of $0.03 per $1</cite> compared to peers.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar size with a focus on educational grants
similar_organizations.name: Rahima Foundation

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focuses on broader community services at a similar scale
similar_organizations.name: Abdul Sattar Edhi International Foundation

strengths.detail: The organization demonstrates remarkable fiscal discipline, incurring a cost of only <cite id="5">$0.03 per $1 raised</cite>, which is significantly lower than industry averages.
TMWF maintains a <cite id="10">100% independent board</cite> and has earned perfect scores of 100 in both <cite id="11">Culture and Leadership</cite> beacons from Charity Navigator.
The foundation provides immediate safety for those in danger, housing <cite id="12">137 emergency shelter residents</cite> according to their most recent 2024 filings.

strengths_deep_dive: Texas Muslim Women's Foundation excels in financial stewardship and transparency. With a <cite id="13">program expense ratio of 86.0%</cite> based on recent filings, the organization ensures a majority of funds reach direct services. Their financial stability is further evidenced by <cite id="14">3.7 months of working capital</cite>, providing a healthy buffer for operations. The organization's growth is also notable, with revenue increasing from <cite id="15">$3,393,180 in 2021 to $4,665,216 in 2023</cite>, allowing for the expansion of critical services like transitional housing and senior support.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 2005, the Texas Muslim Women's Foundation (TMWF) has established itself as a critical provider of domestic violence and social services in North Texas. The organization operates with a high degree of financial efficiency, maintaining an <cite id="1">overall score of 98.98.66666666666667/100 from Charity Navigator</cite>. TMWF's mission centers on empowering women and families through a holistic approach that includes <cite id="2">emergency shelters, transitional housing, and senior programs</cite>. In 2023, the foundation reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $4,665,216</cite>, reflecting a significant <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of 17.3%</cite>. Their operational model is highly lean, spending only <cite id="5">$0.03 to raise every $1 in donations</cite>. Beyond financial health, the organization provides direct relief to vulnerable populations, having supported <cite id="6">186 survivors in shelters</cite> and <cite id="7">204 survivors in transitional or rapid re-housing</cite> during the 2023 fiscal year. As a <cite id="8">zakat-eligible institution</cite>, TMWF allows Muslim donors to direct their obligatory giving toward local humanitarian needs, specifically serving the <cite id="9">fuqara (poor), masakin (needy), and ibn al-sabil (wayfarers)</cite> categories of asnaf.
